## General Notes | Transformation of family-based economic activities in Rural Georgia  {data-background=Occupation_3.png data-background-size=cover } 

> - **Family-based economic activities**; 
> - **Transformation:** starting new economic activities or scaling up existed economic activities;
> - **Rural Georgia:** case study of two rural, mountain municipalities (Mestia, Kazbegi). 

## General Notes | Transformation of family-based economic activities in  **Rural Georgia**  {data-background=Occupation_3.png data-background-size=cover } 

```{r echo = FALSE, message = FALSE, warning=FALSE, fig.height = 3.4, fig.width = 8, dev.args=list(bg='transparent', pointsize=10)}


regions <- readOGR("data/shapefiles/georgia_shape_files/region.shp", verbose=FALSE) 
occupied <- readOGR("data/shapefiles/occupied_territies/occupied_territies.shp", verbose=FALSE) 
municipality <- readOGR("data/shapefiles/municipality/municipaliteti.shp", verbose=FALSE) 
casestudy <- readOGR("data/shapefiles/casestudy/casestudy.shp", verbose=FALSE) 

mapping <- sp::CRS('+proj=longlat +datum=WGS84 +ellps=WGS84 +towgs84=0,0,0')
regions <- sp::spTransform(regions, mapping)
occupied <- sp::spTransform(occupied, mapping)
municipality <- sp::spTransform(municipality, mapping)
casestudy <- sp::spTransform(casestudy, mapping)


respo <- readr::read_csv("data/respo.csv", col_types = cols(mun_geo = "c", number = "n"))
              


regions_2 <- subset(casestudy, is.element(casestudy$mun_geo, respo$mun_geo))
  casestudy_1 <- raster::merge(regions_2, respo, by = "mun_geo", all.x=TRUE)

  
  labels <- paste(
    "Study Area: ", casestudy_1$mun_eng,"<br/>", 
    "Interview Partners: ", casestudy_1$number,"<br/>",
    sep="") %>%
    lapply(htmltools::HTML)
  
map <-  leaflet() %>%
    addTiles() %>%
    
    addPolygons(data = municipality, 
                color = "white",
                weight = 2,
                opacity = 0.5,
                dashArray = "3",
                fillColor = "green",
                fillOpacity = 0.8,)  %>%
  
  addPolygons(data = occupied, 
                color = " #ff5050",
                weight = 2,
                opacity = 1,
                dashArray = "1",
                fillColor = " #ff5050",
                fillOpacity = 1)  %>%
  
  addPolygons(data = casestudy_1, 
                color = "white",
                weight = 2,
                opacity = 1,
                dashArray = "3",
                fillColor = "blue",
                fillOpacity = 0.8,
                highlight = highlightOptions(
                weight = 5,
                color = "#666",
                dashArray = "",
                fillOpacity = 0.7,
                bringToFront = TRUE),
                label = labels,
                labelOptions = labelOptions(
                style = list("font-weight" = "normal", padding = "3px 8px"),
                textsize = "15px",
                direction = "auto"))  %>%
  
  addPolygons(data = regions, 
                color = "#4d0026",
                weight = 2,
                opacity = 0.5,
                dashArray = "1",
                fillColor = "none",
                fillOpacity = 1)  %>%
    
    addMiniMap(
      tiles = providers$Esri.WorldStreetMap,
      toggleDisplay = TRUE)

map

```

## Relevance | Background {data-background=Occupation_3.png data-background-size=cover } 

> - Fragmentation of agricultural land plots owned by local households - Formation subsistence farming;
> - "General Policy Orientation"[@HodgeMidmor2008] from agricultural to rural development;
> - Rural Development Strategy 2017-2020; 
> - LEADER approach put into practice as a pilot project.
 

## Relevance | Distribution of rural population aged 15 and older by economic status {data-background=Occupation_3.png data-background-size=cover } 

```{r  fig.height = 3, fig.width = 10, dev.args=list(bg='transparent', pointsize=10)}


tg_rural <- readxl::read_excel("/Users/macbook/Documents/test/ggplot/ggplot_visuals/data/economic_rural.xlsx")

tg_rural_fl <- dplyr::filter(tg_rural, type != "Not-identified worker" &
                                       rural_urban == "Rural")

tg_p_3 <- ggplot2::ggplot(tg_rural_fl, aes(year, number, color = type))+
          geom_line()+
          geom_point()+
          theme_classic(base_family="Sylfaen")+
          theme(axis.title.x = element_text(colour="black", size=9, hjust=0.5),
                axis.title.y = element_text(colour="black", size=9, hjust=0.5),
                axis.text.x=element_text(angle = 90, hjust=0.5, size=9, colour="black"),
                axis.text.y=element_text(angle = 0, hjust=0.5, size=9, colour="black"),
                plot.title=element_text(colour="black", size=11),
                plot.caption = element_text(size=8, colour="black", hjust=0),
                legend.title=element_text(size=9), 
                legend.text=element_text(size=9),
                legend.position = "right",
                rect = element_rect(fill = "transparent"),
                panel.grid.major = element_line(color="grey85"), 
                panel.grid.minor = element_line(color="grey90"),
                panel.background = element_rect(fill = "transparent",colour = NA),
                plot.background = element_rect(fill = "transparent",colour = NA))+
          labs(caption = "*Time period 2002-2016 is recalculated according to 2014 general population census; The Sampling Frame from 2017 is the 2014 Population Census Database.",
               color="")+
          xlab("Year")+
          ylab("Thousand persons*")+
          scale_color_discrete(name = "Economic Status",
                              labels = c("Hired","Population outside labour force", "Self-employed", "Unemployed"))+
          scale_x_continuous(breaks=seq(1998, 2020, 2))

plotly::ggplotly(tg_p_3)

```

## Research aim {data-background=Occupation_3.png data-background-size=cover } 

To analyze the diversification of family-based economic activities in the context of general policy orientation shift from agricultural to rural policy.

## Methodology {data-background=Occupation_3.png data-background-size=cover } 

- Transformative mixed methods research design [@Driscoll2007];
- Systematic review of literature [@Petticrew2006]; [Connectedpapers](https://www.connectedpapers.com/main/4d8365603a51a0886af162a6c9da8ea18e808a4e/Rural-Tourism-and-Livelihood-Change-An-Emic-Perspective/graph);
- Purposive sampling (maximal variation) [@Patton2015];
- Data collection: in-depth interviews, registration form;
- Qualitative content analysis [@Mayring2000];
- Quantitizing [@Tashakkori1998];

<div class="notes"> 
შერჩევის კრიტერიუმები
•	გეოგრაფიული მდებარეობა;
•	საარსებო წყაროს პრაქტიკა;
•	ოჯახის ტიპი;
•	კაპიტალის მოცულობა.
</div>

## Research findings | Human capitals {data-background=Occupation_3.png data-background-size=cover }

- Obtain financial support (**Financial capital**);

- Contacting new partners (**Social capital**);

- Setting up tourism services (**Social capital, build capital**).

<font size="3"> *"As soon as this [Micro and Small Business Support] program started, some idea came up to start the family business. Since we had built a house, we just wanted to renovate it [make it ready for tourists]. **My parents shared a business idea, I have written it up for [submission], we got the funding**". (Mestia, Guesthouse, young member of the household Pos. 65)* </font>
